item.title: Ghanaian Inflation Hits Three-Year Low, Putting Rate Cut in Play
item.description: Ghana’s annual inflation rate dropped to a more than three-year low as a stronger cedi helped curb import costs, raising the prospect that policymakers may cut borrowing costs later this month.

item.description: The European Central Bank isn’t in a hurry to reduce borrowing costs further following eight cuts in the space of a year, according to Governing Council member Mario Centeno.

item.title: Japan’s Record Tax Haul Leaves Questions Over Ishiba’s Pledge
item.description: Japan’s tax revenues hit a record of around ¥75.2 trillion ($524 billion) in the fiscal year ended March, surpassing government forecasts by ¥1.8 trillion. But the windfall still left questions over how Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba will fund his cash handouts, a key election pledge.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

item.title: RBI Panel Likely to Advise India Retains 4% Inflation Target
item.description: An internal committee of the Reserve Bank of India is in favor of retaining the current inflation target in an upcoming government review, according to people familiar with the matter, giving investors some reassurance about the continuity of monetary policy.

item.title: BOE’s Bailey Says Low UK Debt Making High Rates Less Effective

item.title: BOJ’s Ueda Still Needs More Information to Decide Next Rate Hike
item.description: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda ramped up his message that he is going to wait for additional data to make a judgment on the next monetary policy decision, signaling that he’s in no rush to raise borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka, Francine Lacqua

media:content.media:description: Kazuo Ueda, governor of the Bank of Japan (BOJ), leaves a news conference at the central bank's headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Tuesday, June 17, 2025. The BOJ left its benchmark rate unchanged and unveiled a plan to slow its withdrawal from the bond market from next year in a sign of caution following heightened market volatility.
